Become a member

Sign in










Start taking responsibility for the stuff you build.



Floor DreesFollow



Sep 19, 2018 · 14 min read












Below is the transcript of my CodeDaze 2018 talk.
The Stack Overflow 2018 survey of 100,000 developers provided a ton of insights. Some things remained more or less the same, compared to the outcomes of 2017 and 2016. Major difference: for the first time Stack Overflow included questions about ethics.
Answering the question who is primarily responsible for considering the ramifications of AI, 47.8% of the respondents answer ‘the developers or people creating the AI’, 27.9% answers ‘A governmental or other regulatory body’, 16.6% says ‘prominent industry leaders’ and 7.7% says ‘nobody’.
Whereas 58.5% of the respondents claim they’d never write code for an unethical purpose (define unethical purpose), 36.6% built in a safety net, answering ‘depends what it is’, whilst the remaining 4.8% says they would. I wouldn’t be surprised if the subjective frame of this question reeled some politically-correct answers here, but even if it hasn’t, 40-ish % would probably ‘do evil’.
Respondents overwhelmingly claim that the blame for unethical code rests on ‘management’ (57.5%), or the person who came up with the idea (22.8%), versus the developer who wrote it (19.7%).
Who are we? What do we want?Software makers yield enormous power and yet are still a homogeneous group. Our creations are inherently bias, exclusive and flawed. We have a superpower: we can make computers do things. We build tools, and ultimately responsibility lies with us to think through how those tools will be used.
Let’s talk about the responsibility and accountability we individual builders-of-the-web should claim. Using our exceptional privilege of mostly white, mostly male , sought-after tech workers push for a change.
Push for products and services safe for your users, present and future.
Underrepresented groups are unequally affected by products that are not strictly safe. 1.1 Companies based in the EU are under some pressure to be GDPR compliant. Certainly that pressure could be intensified, were local authorities not so understaffed and uncertain about the way to proceed, dealing with a law that was intentionally kept vague to survive the next decade of technological ‘disruptions’. 1.2. Except for bad data collecting practices, I’ll dive into products that are deliberately addictive or otherwise harming. 1.3 And security.
2. Push for fair working conditions for all.
As an employee of Tesla, Uber and the likes you also hold responsibility over how its warehouse workers, its contractors, gig-economy dependents are treated (and discouraged from unionizing).
3. Push for inclusion of underrepresented groups, on every level.
3.1 In the workforce, and not just for optics. We need to retain these people and make sure they have the same opportunity to advance. 
3.1.2 We can refer people, as long as your network doesn’t comprise of white men only. But refer responsibly, if you know the people you bring in won’t have the opportunities they need and deserve, don’t. 
3.1.3 Dedicate your time to coaching/teaching others, better yet have your management let you do it in company time.
3.2 But also inclusion in the audience you build solutions for.
3.2.1 Push for diverse teams, that uncover the blind spots we have. 
3.2.2 Push for code review standards, Colin’s talk can be a helpful reference. 3.2.3 Push for adopting a CoC for anything your company releases open source, for the local meetups your company sponsors, or conferences you have a booth at.
3.2.4 push for diverse test panels and focus groups.
3.2.5 Push for accessible products, which you should know how, after Adrian’s talk yesterday.
Let me get into these three items one by one.
Pushing for safe products and servicesThe modern approach to data protection relies roughly on the idea that if users were given notice of a company’s data practices and choose to continue using the service, then they consented to those practices. Transferring many of the risks of data processing to users, while maintaining the status quo, is convenient but not fair. To this day, these agreements largely exist to not inform users in an intelligible way.
Consumers more often that not trade data for services without grasping how their information can be stored, shared, used, or even how much their information is worth. Agreements are notoriously vague and present users with take-it-or-leave-it offers that deprive consumers of choice. Real transparency means that the user is fully informed without having to wade through pages full of legalese. Nor by silencing the individuals on your freshly erected board overseeing ethics with an NDA.
The illusion of agency via terms and settings to keep the data machine running is nothing but a lever. We need to create rules that don’t require or even expect users to read these agreements. We need to make our companies trustworthy regardless of the control we are given. We need to make reasonable care the default. It’s not the users responsibility to police the industry.
Defaults matter. I’m going to guess that 90 percent of users don’t change the default settings of a technology product they buy or use within the first six months. Let alone thereafter. In most cases, companies don’t need all that data to provide their services. So what if we flipped the defaults? There’s the approach of lean data practices. Makes for less data to lay out on the street in case of a breach.
What’s good for capturing human attention is bad for humansThe dopamine hits we get from likes on our Instagram photos, gamification elements that do more harm than good. Hooks, those little red dots of notifications piling up. Depression levels are surging, no doubt in some ways fuelled by the Fear of Missing Out.
Few inventions affected our relationship with technology as much as push notifications. Whereas before most of us felt in charge to decide when we want to interact with technology, it is technology that is now largely making that decision for us. Whereas we used to get notified about things that were all about us, we now get notified when random friends like each other’s pumpkin spice latte.
A litany of technologies, like the internet, have contributed immensely to human welfare. Such technologies are worth preserving with rules that mitigate harm but accept reasonable levels of risk. Facial recognition systems however are not among these technologies. Consent rules, procedural requirements, and boilerplate contracts are no match for its risk of exploitation.
The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and other coalition partners urged Amazon to stop providing government agencies with facial recognition technology and services associated with its Rekognition system. The system poses a general problem (no anonymity in public) with unevenly distributed consequence (that are more threatening to minorities and other vulnerable groups), and thus a major threat to civil liberties.
Amazon’s response suggested that if problems ever do arise, appropriate policy correctives should be followed, placing the responsibility with lawmakers. But the irresistible power of a system like Rekognition poses a severe threat in the hands of law enforcement. In a test the ACLU recently conducted of “Rekognition,” the software incorrectly matched 28 members of Congress, identifying them as other people who have been arrested for a crime. Which is why Amazon employees, shareholders, a coalition of nearly 70 civil rights groups, over 400 members of the academic community, and more than 150,000 members of the public have spoken up to demand that Amazon stop providing face surveillance to the government.
Sometimes I think the best course of action might be to avoid the technology all-together, before its use will become the new normal.
Google Duplex deployed human-sounding vocal cues for its bot, such as ‘ums’ and ‘ahs’ — to make its “conversational experience more comfortable”. I don’t think you need to deceive someone to give them a better user experience.
Google let go of it’s don’t be evil slogan as early as 2014, and in my opinion Duplex is just one of the missteps against it’s old claim.
Staff protests forced Google to retreat from the Maven contract in June. Yet Google’s cloud-computing unit, where the company is investing heavily, wants to work with the government and the Department of Defense because they are spending billions of dollars on its services.
In Google’s newly penned up AI principles, the company pledges not to do anything in violation of accepted human rights laws. In a press release it went on to say it will integrate the principles into existing product-review processes and plans to set up an internal review board to enforce the guidelines.
Then, what about the massive, systematic risk posed by our poorly secured home automation devices we’ve indiscriminately connected to the internet? Most modern robots are periodically connected which exposes them to a wide range of threats. There is a large and growing installed base of legacy devices with easily exploitable security flaws, in hospitals and in our homes.
How can we expect inexpensive consumer IoT products to be properly secured when we seem to have difficulty protecting voting systems? There are no widely accepted security standards for IoT devices, and security engineering guidelines are still in the proposal state.
There is no such thing as self-regulationIn 2001, Meg Whitman, then eBay’s chief executive, described the company as a “dynamic self-regulating economy.” When eBay has taken steps to address problems in its economy, it has tended to do so by providing new systems to encourage users to work things out themselves. To deal with sellers who ship slowly or deceive, eBay lets users rate one another. In theory, this starves bad actors out of the marketplace — a poor karma will prevent a seller from selling. In theory.
An Uber driver might be dinged if a rider doesn’t like their personality or choice of music. Facebook tried ranking publishers by trustworthiness, based on feedback from users. Upon discovering a problem, a platform company’s first instinct is to find a way to expose it to the ‘wisdom’ of the crowd. eBay users’ participation in the site’s governance is at its core, snitching on one another.
Normally we think that organizations with a lot of power have an obligation to use that power responsibly. But the leaders of the largest technology companies have by and large resisted thinking of themselves in those terms. They like to think of their sites as neutral platforms that help users share information and connect.
Facebook the Internet not isFacebook’s Internet.org project, bringing internet connectivity to countries underserved, was banned in India for violating net neutrality. Yet, thanks to heavy subsidies that keep Facebook free to use on mobile phones, Facebook has completely saturated countries where it pioneered, like the Filippines. Because using other data is expensive, for most Filipinos the only way online is through Facebook.
Roughly 69 million Filipinos have access to the internet today, and 97 percent of them have a Facebook account. I don’t need to remind you that Facebook’s News Feed algorithm promotes anything that attracts attention, amplifying bad actors.
Fair working conditions for allThe funny thing about the tech industry’s narrative about itself, is that failure was always assumed to be temporary (bugs can be fixed); where for everyone else, it’s devastating. Taxicab companies going out of business because they’re losing money is considered great creative disruption. This double standard justifies the exploitation of Uber drivers hardly making a living.
Mechanical Turk is bot-ridden largely because of the unfair compensation, yet we rely on it for (social science) research. That doesn’t seem right.
Healthy working conditions too, where everyone can largely participate by default. Last year I interviewed with a FinTech startup, which name starts with an R and ends with Evolut, and my 2 consecutive interviewers told me 100h workweeks were no abnormality and challenged me that I couldn’t keep up being a mom, which is prolly true, and I wouldn’t want to, not as a mom and not as a human being, but that’s besides the fact that they shouldn’t have this information in the first place. Also: equal parental leave.
One of DHH’s most recent Twitter storms revolved around a company promoting crazy hours in their job ad.
Inclusion of underrepresented groupsBad inputs lead to bad outputsBecause machine learning technology is deployed by governments and companies in fields ranging from criminal justice to recruitment, workforce biases in the tech sector are amplified across other industries and the public sector. AI algorithms learn from historic data sets, so they are more likely to hire in the image of previous staff instead of helping to tackle unfair under-representation.
Big tech, and specifically social networks are mostly limited by a workforce that doesn’t understand what abuse looks and feels like. Equal opportunity today looks like this: the internet is the modern front line of feminism, amplifying the voices of (predominantly white) women around the world, as much as it provides space for so-called ‘Men’s Rights Activists’ to form alliances.
The ramifications online affect different people in different ways, precisely because of the inequity of the society it mirrors. It affects men and women differently. But more-over it affects people of colour differently. It affects trans and gender fluid people differently. It affects people differently on a whole spectrum.
A handful of tech giants have become the self-proclaimed guardians of global speech, amplifying certain kinds of voices and limiting others, referring to their often opaque and shifting standards. Although these companies — Facebook, Google and Twitter above all — are now integral to just about every corner of our lives, yet face little regulatory oversight.
Facebook is the largest media company in the world and Zuckerberg the most powerful publisher. Twitter is a smaller media company, yes, but still wildly influential in many ways, not least of all because it is known for being the platform of choice among celebrities, politicians, and journalists. Also: conspiracy theorists.
Twitter founder Jack Dorsey rejects the idea that publishers are responsible for the quality of what appears on their platforms. Instead we should know to rely on other publishers to uphold standards such as seeking the truth.
Systems users rely on are ridden with hidden, pervasive and often unintended bias — the sort that led Google to return pictures of black people for searches of “gorilla.” Google is made by humans who have preferences, opinions and blind spots and who work within a corporate structure that has clear financial and political goals. Not to say that not for profit or open source organisations are inheritely inclusive, as Coraline pointed out in her EuRuKo talk The Broken Promise of Open Source, last month.
Because Google’s systems are increasingly created by artificial intelligence tools that learn from real-world data, there’s a growing possibility that it will amplify the many biases found in society. And it’s not just search. Google owns YouTube and Gmail, and it makes the Android operating system and its app store. It is the world’s dominant internet advertising company, and through that business, it also shapes the market for digital news. Google’s algorithms favor recency and activity, which makes it vulnerable to being manipulated in favor of misinformation.
Diverse teams are more likely to flag problems that could have negative social consequences before a product has been launched. Diversity campaigns at companies such as Google have failed to significantly shift the predominance of white cis het and Asian men in their technical workforces.
So what are we to do?Ask why. A lot. Why do we need this feature, this product? Why do we need to track users every move? Why do we need another white male hire? Another white male consulting team? Why is this person not involved in this meeting? Encourage your team to follow your example. More than 4,000 employees signed a petition calling for the cancellation of Google’s Project Maven contract, some even resigned over the topic. We are with that 4,000.
Don’t be the douche hiding behind the “I am just the developer” line. Being a good software engineer does not qualify you to engineer society, politics, economics, and beyond. But that’s exactly what we’re doing, every day. As tech companies take on increasingly vital roles in global commerce and culture, we have the power to shape the way they operate and the ethical standards they abide to. Tech workers are the only point of leverage because we’re no commodity (until we’re replaced by robots and have to survive on UBI).
When you invent the ship, you also invent the shipwreckThe famous Paul Virilio quote above applies well to the effort Apple and Google claim where they announce features to help people cut back on their tech use.. Even Instagram has recognized the “zombie scrolling” phenomenon and rolled out a new interface to help users break the habit.
While at first glance, it appears their business model would benefit from addiction — the more you use your phone, the more money they make through the apps you buy and the ads you view — for their long term goals however, Apple and Google don’t want you to get addicted. Addiction is a compulsive and harmful behavior. And they rather see you form healthy habits with your digital devices.
Incorporating safety features, their behaviour mimicks that of car makers introducing seat belts in the 1950s.
Facebook and Twitter are attempting to curb toxic behaviour on their platforms. If only they wouldn’t solely rely on the worst technology to do so, AI. Healthy discourse can’t be engineered, even if it’s compelling to try. Until there are real consequences to insults, harassment and deception, the conversation cannot be healthy.
Google wants to cut fake news sites off from access to its vast advertising network, depriving them of a key revenue source. Facebook quickly followed suit with its own ad network. Social media has drastically lowered barriers to entry in the news business. Twitter, Google, and especially Facebook have gained a huge and growing influence over what news people see. It only makes sense that they fix the problem.
There have been proponents of ending anonymity on Twitter. I wonder if the trade-off would be worth it? Could Arab Spring have taken place on a platform that needs verification for you to participate? Anonymity is necessary, but what if not you perse, but someone or something (some entity) could lend you verification? An interesting discussion to have.
I’d urge you not to take requests at face value. Technology is moving so fast. There is no way laws can ever keep up. We only seem to ask ourselves “Can we do this?” “Sure, we’ll just move fast and break stuff.” And we never stop and ask “Should we do this?”
How can organisations working at the bleeding edge of technology design for and invest in process that informs governance and operationalises ethics when the critical analysis of unintended effects largely takes place outside of the locus of invention. Today the process of inventing is not influenced by critical analysis.
The author of the article ‘Working ethically at speed’ proposes a setup of agile ethics, borrowing from the agile development method. A process whereby ideas are researched, prototyped, and then shaped by frequent testing with a potential user group, preventing harmful creations from being flung into the world before their potential impacts are assessed. When non-diverse teams use agile methods they often have ethical blind spots (wilful and not) that can embed harm in what they build. Agile ethics is a process to operationalise values, identify and address ethical challenges of our innovations, and iteratively refine once you launched.
Hayley’s talk about licensure yesterday rang true to me. As a society, we recognize that when consumers dine out, they may be putting their health at risk. Public information about interacting in the digital world is lacking, which is striking given the relative severity of the threat. Many disciplines have to take some equivalent of the Hippocratic oath. But not us. Why?
The First Amendment does not apply to private companies — but these companies are so powerful that their decisions do have political consequences. PayPal began to prohibit donations that “promote hate, violence and intolerance.” GoDaddy and Google refused to host a neo-Nazi website.
Giphy was recently booted by Snapchat and Instagram after an explicitly racist GIF outraged users — and Giphy responded by cleaning out its database, signifying a shift in how we hold social media platforms accountable. Volunteers step up to combat conspiracy theorists on Wikipedia. Not all hope, it seems, is lost.
The effects of decisions or actions based on AI are often the result of countless interactions among many actors, including designers, developers, users, software, and hardware. This is known as distributed agency. With distributed agency comes distributed responsibility.
Existing ethical frameworks like AI4People and IEEE, the European Union (EU) strategy for AI, the EU Declaration of Cooperation on Artificial Intelligence, and the Partnership on Artificial Intelligence to Benefit People and Society are so important, yet largely unknown to most of us in this room. Let’s change that.
Thank you.
Also, please watch Thompson’s chilling talk ‘Don’t get Distracted’.
















Tech
Ethics
Engineering Ethics
Bias
Software














Written by

Floor DreesFollow


Product Marketing Manager at Microsoft (Azure). Mom to 1 human, 1 dachshund and ~100 plants.
Follow

Become a member

Start taking responsibility for the stuff you build.

Floor Drees
Sep 19, 2018 · 14 min read

Below is the transcript of my CodeDaze 2018 talk.

The Stack Overflow 2018 survey of 100,000 developers provided a ton of insights. Some things remained more or less the same, compared to the outcomes of 2017 and 2016. Major difference: for the first time Stack Overflow included questions about ethics.

Answering the question who is primarily responsible for considering the ramifications of AI, 47.8% of the respondents answer ‘the developers or people creating the AI’, 27.9% answers ‘A governmental or other regulatory body’, 16.6% says ‘prominent industry leaders’ and 7.7% says ‘nobody’.

Whereas 58.5% of the respondents claim they’d never write code for an unethical purpose (define unethical purpose), 36.6% built in a safety net, answering ‘depends what it is’, whilst the remaining 4.8% says they would. I wouldn’t be surprised if the subjective frame of this question reeled some politically-correct answers here, but even if it hasn’t, 40-ish % would probably ‘do evil’.

Respondents overwhelmingly claim that the blame for unethical code rests on ‘management’ (57.5%), or the person who came up with the idea (22.8%), versus the developer who wrote it (19.7%).

Who are we? What do we want?

Software makers yield enormous power and yet are still a homogeneous group. Our creations are inherently bias, exclusive and flawed. We have a superpower: we can make computers do things. We build tools, and ultimately responsibility lies with us to think through how those tools will be used.

Let’s talk about the responsibility and accountability we individual builders-of-the-web should claim. Using our exceptional privilege of mostly white, mostly male , sought-after tech workers push for a change.

  1. Push for products and services safe for your users, present and future.

Underrepresented groups are unequally affected by products that are not strictly safe. 1.1 Companies based in the EU are under some pressure to be GDPR compliant. Certainly that pressure could be intensified, were local authorities not so understaffed and uncertain about the way to proceed, dealing with a law that was intentionally kept vague to survive the next decade of technological ‘disruptions’. 1.2. Except for bad data collecting practices, I’ll dive into products that are deliberately addictive or otherwise harming. 1.3 And security.

2. Push for fair working conditions for all.

As an employee of Tesla, Uber and the likes you also hold responsibility over how its warehouse workers, its contractors, gig-economy dependents are treated (and discouraged from unionizing).

3. Push for inclusion of underrepresented groups, on every level.

3.1 In the workforce, and not just for optics. We need to retain these people and make sure they have the same opportunity to advance.
3.1.2 We can refer people, as long as your network doesn’t comprise of white men only. But refer responsibly, if you know the people you bring in won’t have the opportunities they need and deserve, don’t.
3.1.3 Dedicate your time to coaching/teaching others, better yet have your management let you do it in company time.

3.2 But also inclusion in the audience you build solutions for.
3.2.1 Push for diverse teams, that uncover the blind spots we have.
3.2.2 Push for code review standards, Colin’s talk can be a helpful reference. 3.2.3 Push for adopting a CoC for anything your company releases open source, for the local meetups your company sponsors, or conferences you have a booth at.
3.2.4 push for diverse test panels and focus groups.
3.2.5 Push for accessible products, which you should know how, after Adrian’s talk yesterday.

Let me get into these three items one by one.

Pushing for safe products and services

The modern approach to data protection relies roughly on the idea that if users were given notice of a company’s data practices and choose to continue using the service, then they consented to those practices. Transferring many of the risks of data processing to users, while maintaining the status quo, is convenient but not fair. To this day, these agreements largely exist to not inform users in an intelligible way.

Consumers more often that not trade data for services without grasping how their information can be stored, shared, used, or even how much their information is worth. Agreements are notoriously vague and present users with take-it-or-leave-it offers that deprive consumers of choice. Real transparency means that the user is fully informed without having to wade through pages full of legalese. Nor by silencing the individuals on your freshly erected board overseeing ethics with an NDA.

The illusion of agency via terms and settings to keep the data machine running is nothing but a lever. We need to create rules that don’t require or even expect users to read these agreements. We need to make our companies trustworthy regardless of the control we are given. We need to make reasonable care the default. It’s not the users responsibility to police the industry.

Defaults matter. I’m going to guess that 90 percent of users don’t change the default settings of a technology product they buy or use within the first six months. Let alone thereafter. In most cases, companies don’t need all that data to provide their services. So what if we flipped the defaults? There’s the approach of lean data practices. Makes for less data to lay out on the street in case of a breach.

What’s good for capturing human attention is bad for humans

The dopamine hits we get from likes on our Instagram photos, gamification elements that do more harm than good. Hooks, those little red dots of notifications piling up. Depression levels are surging, no doubt in some ways fuelled by the Fear of Missing Out.

Few inventions affected our relationship with technology as much as push notifications. Whereas before most of us felt in charge to decide when we want to interact with technology, it is technology that is now largely making that decision for us. Whereas we used to get notified about things that were all about us, we now get notified when random friends like each other’s pumpkin spice latte.

A litany of technologies, like the internet, have contributed immensely to human welfare. Such technologies are worth preserving with rules that mitigate harm but accept reasonable levels of risk. Facial recognition systems however are not among these technologies. Consent rules, procedural requirements, and boilerplate contracts are no match for its risk of exploitation.

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and other coalition partners urged Amazon to stop providing government agencies with facial recognition technology and services associated with its Rekognition system. The system poses a general problem (no anonymity in public) with unevenly distributed consequence (that are more threatening to minorities and other vulnerable groups), and thus a major threat to civil liberties.

Amazon’s response suggested that if problems ever do arise, appropriate policy correctives should be followed, placing the responsibility with lawmakers. But the irresistible power of a system like Rekognition poses a severe threat in the hands of law enforcement. In a test the ACLU recently conducted of “Rekognition,” the software incorrectly matched 28 members of Congress, identifying them as other people who have been arrested for a crime. Which is why Amazon employees, shareholders, a coalition of nearly 70 civil rights groups, over 400 members of the academic community, and more than 150,000 members of the public have spoken up to demand that Amazon stop providing face surveillance to the government.

Sometimes I think the best course of action might be to avoid the technology all-together, before its use will become the new normal.

Google Duplex deployed human-sounding vocal cues for its bot, such as ‘ums’ and ‘ahs’ — to make its “conversational experience more comfortable”. I don’t think you need to deceive someone to give them a better user experience.
Google let go of it’s don’t be evil slogan as early as 2014, and in my opinion Duplex is just one of the missteps against it’s old claim.

Staff protests forced Google to retreat from the Maven contract in June. Yet Google’s cloud-computing unit, where the company is investing heavily, wants to work with the government and the Department of Defense because they are spending billions of dollars on its services.

In Google’s newly penned up AI principles, the company pledges not to do anything in violation of accepted human rights laws. In a press release it went on to say it will integrate the principles into existing product-review processes and plans to set up an internal review board to enforce the guidelines.

Then, what about the massive, systematic risk posed by our poorly secured home automation devices we’ve indiscriminately connected to the internet? Most modern robots are periodically connected which exposes them to a wide range of threats. There is a large and growing installed base of legacy devices with easily exploitable security flaws, in hospitals and in our homes.

How can we expect inexpensive consumer IoT products to be properly secured when we seem to have difficulty protecting voting systems? There are no widely accepted security standards for IoT devices, and security engineering guidelines are still in the proposal state.

There is no such thing as self-regulation

In 2001, Meg Whitman, then eBay’s chief executive, described the company as a “dynamic self-regulating economy.” When eBay has taken steps to address problems in its economy, it has tended to do so by providing new systems to encourage users to work things out themselves. To deal with sellers who ship slowly or deceive, eBay lets users rate one another. In theory, this starves bad actors out of the marketplace — a poor karma will prevent a seller from selling. In theory.

An Uber driver might be dinged if a rider doesn’t like their personality or choice of music. Facebook tried ranking publishers by trustworthiness, based on feedback from users. Upon discovering a problem, a platform company’s first instinct is to find a way to expose it to the ‘wisdom’ of the crowd. eBay users’ participation in the site’s governance is at its core, snitching on one another.

Normally we think that organizations with a lot of power have an obligation to use that power responsibly. But the leaders of the largest technology companies have by and large resisted thinking of themselves in those terms. They like to think of their sites as neutral platforms that help users share information and connect.

Facebook the Internet not is

Facebook’s Internet.org project, bringing internet connectivity to countries underserved, was banned in India for violating net neutrality. Yet, thanks to heavy subsidies that keep Facebook free to use on mobile phones, Facebook has completely saturated countries where it pioneered, like the Filippines. Because using other data is expensive, for most Filipinos the only way online is through Facebook.

Roughly 69 million Filipinos have access to the internet today, and 97 percent of them have a Facebook account. I don’t need to remind you that Facebook’s News Feed algorithm promotes anything that attracts attention, amplifying bad actors.

Fair working conditions for all

The funny thing about the tech industry’s narrative about itself, is that failure was always assumed to be temporary (bugs can be fixed); where for everyone else, it’s devastating. Taxicab companies going out of business because they’re losing money is considered great creative disruption. This double standard justifies the exploitation of Uber drivers hardly making a living.
Mechanical Turk is bot-ridden largely because of the unfair compensation, yet we rely on it for (social science) research. That doesn’t seem right.

Healthy working conditions too, where everyone can largely participate by default. Last year I interviewed with a FinTech startup, which name starts with an R and ends with Evolut, and my 2 consecutive interviewers told me 100h workweeks were no abnormality and challenged me that I couldn’t keep up being a mom, which is prolly true, and I wouldn’t want to, not as a mom and not as a human being, but that’s besides the fact that they shouldn’t have this information in the first place. Also: equal parental leave.

One of DHH’s most recent Twitter storms revolved around a company promoting crazy hours in their job ad.

Inclusion of underrepresented groups

Bad inputs lead to bad outputs

Because machine learning technology is deployed by governments and companies in fields ranging from criminal justice to recruitment, workforce biases in the tech sector are amplified across other industries and the public sector. AI algorithms learn from historic data sets, so they are more likely to hire in the image of previous staff instead of helping to tackle unfair under-representation.

Big tech, and specifically social networks are mostly limited by a workforce that doesn’t understand what abuse looks and feels like. Equal opportunity today looks like this: the internet is the modern front line of feminism, amplifying the voices of (predominantly white) women around the world, as much as it provides space for so-called ‘Men’s Rights Activists’ to form alliances.

The ramifications online affect different people in different ways, precisely because of the inequity of the society it mirrors. It affects men and women differently. But more-over it affects people of colour differently. It affects trans and gender fluid people differently. It affects people differently on a whole spectrum.

A handful of tech giants have become the self-proclaimed guardians of global speech, amplifying certain kinds of voices and limiting others, referring to their often opaque and shifting standards. Although these companies — Facebook, Google and Twitter above all — are now integral to just about every corner of our lives, yet face little regulatory oversight.

Facebook is the largest media company in the world and Zuckerberg the most powerful publisher. Twitter is a smaller media company, yes, but still wildly influential in many ways, not least of all because it is known for being the platform of choice among celebrities, politicians, and journalists. Also: conspiracy theorists.

Twitter founder Jack Dorsey rejects the idea that publishers are responsible for the quality of what appears on their platforms. Instead we should know to rely on other publishers to uphold standards such as seeking the truth.
Systems users rely on are ridden with hidden, pervasive and often unintended bias — the sort that led Google to return pictures of black people for searches of “gorilla.” Google is made by humans who have preferences, opinions and blind spots and who work within a corporate structure that has clear financial and political goals. Not to say that not for profit or open source organisations are inheritely inclusive, as Coraline pointed out in her EuRuKo talk The Broken Promise of Open Source, last month.

Because Google’s systems are increasingly created by artificial intelligence tools that learn from real-world data, there’s a growing possibility that it will amplify the many biases found in society. And it’s not just search. Google owns YouTube and Gmail, and it makes the Android operating system and its app store. It is the world’s dominant internet advertising company, and through that business, it also shapes the market for digital news. Google’s algorithms favor recency and activity, which makes it vulnerable to being manipulated in favor of misinformation.

Diverse teams are more likely to flag problems that could have negative social consequences before a product has been launched. Diversity campaigns at companies such as Google have failed to significantly shift the predominance of white cis het and Asian men in their technical workforces.

So what are we to do?

Ask why. A lot. Why do we need this feature, this product? Why do we need to track users every move? Why do we need another white male hire? Another white male consulting team? Why is this person not involved in this meeting? Encourage your team to follow your example. More than 4,000 employees signed a petition calling for the cancellation of Google’s Project Maven contract, some even resigned over the topic. We are with that 4,000.

Don’t be the douche hiding behind the “I am just the developer” line. Being a good software engineer does not qualify you to engineer society, politics, economics, and beyond. But that’s exactly what we’re doing, every day. As tech companies take on increasingly vital roles in global commerce and culture, we have the power to shape the way they operate and the ethical standards they abide to. Tech workers are the only point of leverage because we’re no commodity (until we’re replaced by robots and have to survive on UBI).

When you invent the ship, you also invent the shipwreck

The famous Paul Virilio quote above applies well to the effort Apple and Google claim where they announce features to help people cut back on their tech use.. Even Instagram has recognized the “zombie scrolling” phenomenon and rolled out a new interface to help users break the habit.

While at first glance, it appears their business model would benefit from addiction — the more you use your phone, the more money they make through the apps you buy and the ads you view — for their long term goals however, Apple and Google don’t want you to get addicted. Addiction is a compulsive and harmful behavior. And they rather see you form healthy habits with your digital devices.

Incorporating safety features, their behaviour mimicks that of car makers introducing seat belts in the 1950s.

Facebook and Twitter are attempting to curb toxic behaviour on their platforms. If only they wouldn’t solely rely on the worst technology to do so, AI. Healthy discourse can’t be engineered, even if it’s compelling to try. Until there are real consequences to insults, harassment and deception, the conversation cannot be healthy.

Google wants to cut fake news sites off from access to its vast advertising network, depriving them of a key revenue source. Facebook quickly followed suit with its own ad network. Social media has drastically lowered barriers to entry in the news business. Twitter, Google, and especially Facebook have gained a huge and growing influence over what news people see. It only makes sense that they fix the problem.

There have been proponents of ending anonymity on Twitter. I wonder if the trade-off would be worth it? Could Arab Spring have taken place on a platform that needs verification for you to participate? Anonymity is necessary, but what if not you perse, but someone or something (some entity) could lend you verification? An interesting discussion to have.

I’d urge you not to take requests at face value. Technology is moving so fast. There is no way laws can ever keep up. We only seem to ask ourselves “Can we do this?” “Sure, we’ll just move fast and break stuff.” And we never stop and ask “Should we do this?”

How can organisations working at the bleeding edge of technology design for and invest in process that informs governance and operationalises ethics when the critical analysis of unintended effects largely takes place outside of the locus of invention. Today the process of inventing is not influenced by critical analysis.

The author of the article ‘Working ethically at speed’ proposes a setup of agile ethics, borrowing from the agile development method. A process whereby ideas are researched, prototyped, and then shaped by frequent testing with a potential user group, preventing harmful creations from being flung into the world before their potential impacts are assessed. When non-diverse teams use agile methods they often have ethical blind spots (wilful and not) that can embed harm in what they build. Agile ethics is a process to operationalise values, identify and address ethical challenges of our innovations, and iteratively refine once you launched.

Hayley’s talk about licensure yesterday rang true to me. As a society, we recognize that when consumers dine out, they may be putting their health at risk. Public information about interacting in the digital world is lacking, which is striking given the relative severity of the threat. Many disciplines have to take some equivalent of the Hippocratic oath. But not us. Why?

The First Amendment does not apply to private companies — but these companies are so powerful that their decisions do have political consequences. PayPal began to prohibit donations that “promote hate, violence and intolerance.” GoDaddy and Google refused to host a neo-Nazi website.

Giphy was recently booted by Snapchat and Instagram after an explicitly racist GIF outraged users — and Giphy responded by cleaning out its database, signifying a shift in how we hold social media platforms accountable. Volunteers step up to combat conspiracy theorists on Wikipedia. Not all hope, it seems, is lost.

The effects of decisions or actions based on AI are often the result of countless interactions among many actors, including designers, developers, users, software, and hardware. This is known as distributed agency. With distributed agency comes distributed responsibility.

Existing ethical frameworks like AI4People and IEEE, the European Union (EU) strategy for AI, the EU Declaration of Cooperation on Artificial Intelligence, and the Partnership on Artificial Intelligence to Benefit People and Society are so important, yet largely unknown to most of us in this room. Let’s change that.

Thank you.
Also, please watch Thompson’s chilling talk ‘Don’t get Distracted’.
